Problem:
Consider a linear algebra problem involving an initial matrix \u0027X\u0027. The function \u0027f(X) = e^{At}X\u0027 transforms \u0027X\u0027 over time \u0027t\u0027, where \u0027A\u0027 is a constant skew-symmetric matrix. This explores changes under the integral transformation using the Laplace Transform of \u0027X\u0027.

If \u0027f(X)\u0027 is applied at time \u0027t = 0\u0027 to an initial matrix \u0027X_0\u0027 and subsequently evolves without further transformations under natural properties, will the spectrum of \u0027X(t)\u0027 at \u0027t = T\u0027 be the same as without applying \u0027f(X)\u0027?
Explanation: Since \u0027A\u0027 is skew-symmetric, the exponential matrix \u0027e^{At}\u0027 is orthogonal. Orthogonal transformations preserve the spectrum of a matrix. Therefore, the spectrum of \u0027X(t)\u0027 remains unchanged regardless of the initial application of \u0027f(X)\u0027.
